Title: Why Taoists Avoid Pride ï½œ Tao Te Ching Chapter 24 Explained

Content.Knowledge Point: The dangers of standing on tiptoe, striding ahead, making extravagant displays, and justifying oneself.
Content.Text: Those who stand on tiptoe are not steady. Those who stride out ahead will soon fall behind. Those who make a big show are far from enlightenment. Those who think they can never be wrong are not respected. Those who justify themselves have no merit. Those who boast will not last long.

Content.Knowledge Point: The importance of inner cultivation and self-worth.
Content.Text: All throughout the Tao Te Ching, we are advised to take care of our inner world, to learn to adopt a feeling of self-worth, and to learn to be a better person.

Content.Knowledge Point: The analogy of overeating and the urge to boast.
Content.Text: The urge to overeat and the urge to boast, show off, or otherwise aggrandize ourselves run along the same lines. We must learn to master these instincts.

Content.Knowledge Point: The need for love and appreciation and the importance of conscious decision-making.
Content.Text: The need for love and appreciation is not evil any more than the need to eat is evil. It's up to us to make conscious decisions about which methods we will pursue.
